text:
Government remains committed to North East devolution despite cabinet reshuffle 05:30, 19 Jul 2016 In his last act as Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government Greg Clark attempted to reassure regional leaders about devolution Shares Get daily news by email Communities Secretary Greg Clark 
In his last act as the minister responsible for devolution , Greg Clark MP sought to reassure North East leaders that the Government remained committed to a mayoral authority in the region. 
The multi-billion pound devolution deal was shelved on July 4 after a number of concerns were raised by the leaders of the seven North East local authorities about funding arrangements post Brexit. 
Mr Clark sent a letter urging leaders to push on - emphasising that devolution was “more important than ever”. 
In regards to the potential impact on EU funds , Mr Clark recognised the concerns of the North East and stated that work was ongoing to ensure that the implication for local economies and the role of EU funds is fully considered and that an update on future funding will be provided shortly. 
However just hours after the letter was received on July 13, Mr Clark was switched with Sajid Javid at the Department for Business, Enterprise and Regulatory Reform. 
Mr Javid took to Twitter after the switch in a bid to calm nerves that the Government’s agenda had changed. 
He said: “My priorities are to build more homes and increase home ownership, devolve powers to local areas and help communities deliver excellent public services.” 
Whether the Government has done enough to reassure the leaders of Newcastle, Sunderland, Northumberland, Durham, South Tyneside and North Tyneside that devolution is the only way forward will become clear when they meet on Tuesday. 
The agreement guarantees £30m a year for the region to spend – in addition to being given control of a £3.4bn pool of investment cash. 
The North East would also get new powers covering employment and skills, transport and planning and business activity – all intended to drive economic growth. More on the North's devolution deal
